content.raw:
I see an error in the launch \(we need to improve the launch files\):

```shell
[ERROR] [1519239265.184685521]: PluginlibFactory: The plugin for class 'rviz_plugin_tutorials/Imu' failed to load.  Error: According to the loaded plugin descriptions the class rviz_plugin_tutorials/Imu with base class type rviz::Display does not exist. Declared types are  rviz/Axes rviz/Camera rviz/DepthCloud rviz/Effort rviz/FluidPressure rviz/Grid rviz/GridCells rviz/Illuminance rviz/Image rviz/InteractiveMarkers rviz/LaserScan rviz/Map rviz/Marker rviz/MarkerArray rviz/Odometry rviz/Path rviz/PointCloud rviz/PointCloud2 rviz/PointStamped rviz/Polygon rviz/Pose rviz/PoseArray rviz/PoseWithCovariance rviz/Range rviz/RelativeHumidity rviz/RobotModel rviz/TF rviz/Temperature rviz/WrenchStamped
```

Is it somehow important or we can ignore it?

pull_request.title: Add servicesim job to job DSLs.

pullrequest.title: Add servicesim job to job DSLs.

content.raw:
Louise is correct. catkin_tools couldn't successfully compile the project in a local workspace and I haven't yet investigated why. Because the script is shared among projects and catkin_tools has more user friendly output, I didn't want to unilaterally switch the script to catkin_make_isolated. So I copied it for a quick fix.

We could set a BUILD_TOOL variable or somesuch and use catkin_make_isolated or catkin_tools based on that variable, defaulting to catkin_tools. That would allow me to fold my changes back into the original ros_setup_buildsh script.
content.html:
Louise is correct. catkin_tools couldn't successfully compile the project in a local workspace and I haven't yet investigated why. Because the script is shared among projects and catkin_tools has more user friendly output, I didn't want to unilaterally switch the script to catkin_make_isolated. So I copied it for a quick fix.

We could set a BUILD_TOOL variable or somesuch and use catkin_make_isolated or catkin_tools based on that variable, defaulting to catkin_tools. That would allow me to fold my changes back into the original ros_setup_buildsh script.

pull_request.title: Add servicesim job to job DSLs.

pullrequest.title: Add servicesim job to job DSLs.

content.raw:
I believe catkin build was not behaving properly for our use case, but make isolated did. In particular, the tests package `servicesim_test` was not being able to find the others.

It is also my understanding that the ROS buildfarm uses `catkin_make_isolated` (I haven't checked this myself).

So if we want to keep a single script, maybe we could consider using `catkin_make_isolated` on the original script?
content.html:
I believe catkin build was not behaving properly for our use case, but make isolated did. In particular, the tests package servicesim_test was not being able to find the others.

It is also my understanding that the ROS buildfarm uses catkin_make_isolated (I haven't checked this myself).

So if we want to keep a single script, maybe we could consider using catkin_make_isolated on the original script?

content.raw: We are not including an `smoke test`that just run the main launch file of the software during a few seconds. I found this useful to detect many defects and problems in software \(ABI breakages, missing dependencies, ...\). You can give a look into the [example of gazebo\_ros\_pkgs](#!/osrf/release-tools/src/15d92a5da840b16c83cf07937a6c7bfd019f1464/jenkins-scripts/docker/lib/gazebo_ros_pkgs-check-release.bash?at=default&fileviewer=file-view-default#gazebo_ros_pkgs-check-release.bash-54) to create one.
content.html: We are not including an smoke testthat just run the main launch file of the software during a few seconds. I found this useful to detect many defects and problems in software (ABI breakages, missing dependencies, ...). You can give a look into the example of gazebo_ros_pkgs to create one.

content.raw: libgazeboX-dev does not automatically depend on gazeboX. The build is fine since it is not probably to run gzclient/gzserver but if at some point we want it, we need to add gazebo$\{PKG\_VERSION\} here.
content.html: libgazeboX-dev does not automatically depend on gazeboX. The build is fine since it is not probably to run gzclient/gzserver but if at some point we want it, we need to add gazebo${PKG_VERSION} here.

content.raw:
The `_ros_setup_catkin_make_isolated_buildsh.bash`script differs with the current `_ros_setup_buildsh.bash`just in the use of catkin\_make instead of catkin\_tools. 

```diff
--- _ros_setup_buildsh.bash	2018-01-15 00:37:12.640969303 +0100
+++ _ros_setup_catkin_make_isolated_buildsh.bash	2018-02-21 00:09:12.616622938 +0100
@@ -54,9 +54,7 @@
 rm -fr ${CATKIN_WS}
 mkdir -p ${CATKIN_WS}/src
 cd ${CATKIN_WS}
-catkin config --init --mkdirs
 ln -s "${WORKSPACE}/${SOFTWARE_DIR}" "${CATKIN_WS}/src/${SOFTWARE_DIR}"
-catkin list
 echo '# END SECTION'
 DELIM_CONFIG
 
@@ -72,7 +70,6 @@
 echo '# END SECTION'
 
 echo '# BEGIN SECTION install the system dependencies'
-catkin list
 rosdep install --from-paths . \
                --ignore-src   \
                --rosdistro=${ROS_DISTRO} \
@@ -81,11 +78,11 @@
 echo '# END SECTION'
 
 echo '# BEGIN SECTION compile the catkin workspace'
-catkin build -j${MAKE_JOBS} --verbose --summary
+catkin_make_isolated -j${MAKE_JOBS}
 echo '# END SECTION'
 
 echo '# BEGIN SECTION: running tests'
-catkin run_tests -j1 || true
+catkin_make_isolated --catkin-make-args run_tests -j1 || true
 catkin_test_results --all --verbose || true
 
 # link test results to usual place
```

I don't have an strong preference but we should only maintain one version of them. Any problem using the current script with catkin tools?
content.html:
The _ros_setup_catkin_make_isolated_buildsh.bashscript differs with the current _ros_setup_buildsh.bashjust in the use of catkin_make instead of catkin_tools. 

--- _ros_setup_buildsh.bash 2018-01-15 00:37:12.640969303 +0100
+++ _ros_setup_catkin_make_isolated_buildsh.bash    2018-02-21 00:09:12.616622938 +0100
@@ -54,9 +54,7 @@
 rm -fr ${CATKIN_WS}
 mkdir -p ${CATKIN_WS}/src
 cd ${CATKIN_WS}
-catkin config --init --mkdirs
 ln -s "${WORKSPACE}/${SOFTWARE_DIR}" "${CATKIN_WS}/src/${SOFTWARE_DIR}"
-catkin list
 echo '# END SECTION'
 DELIM_CONFIG

@@ -72,7 +70,6 @@
 echo '# END SECTION'

 echo '# BEGIN SECTION install the system dependencies'
-catkin list
 rosdep install --from-paths . \
                --ignore-src   \
                --rosdistro=${ROS_DISTRO} \
@@ -81,11 +78,11 @@
 echo '# END SECTION'

 echo '# BEGIN SECTION compile the catkin workspace'
-catkin build -j${MAKE_JOBS} --verbose --summary
+catkin_make_isolated -j${MAKE_JOBS}
 echo '# END SECTION'

 echo '# BEGIN SECTION: running tests'
-catkin run_tests -j1 || true
+catkin_make_isolated --catkin-make-args run_tests -j1 || true
 catkin_test_results --all --verbose || true

 # link test results to usual place

I don't have an strong preference but we should only maintain one version of them. Any problem using the current script with catkin tools?

content.raw: I've simplified the gpu tagging mechanism in [8a1262a](#!/osrf/release-tools/commits/8a1262a92aedd48edfa2799c3d45646116e45dc3?at=default) . Remove the function since we only support one distro \(no more logic needed\) and use the generic `gpu-reliable`. We don't need to use `gpu-reliable-${distro}` anymore since we transitioned to nvidia-docker which handles GPU support in docker transparently.
content.html: I've simplified the gpu tagging mechanism in 8a1262a . Remove the function since we only support one distro (no more logic needed) and use the generic gpu-reliable. We don't need to use gpu-reliable-${distro} anymore since we transitioned to nvidia-docker which handles GPU support in docker transparently.

pull_request.title: Add servicesim job to job DSLs.

pullrequest.title: Add servicesim job to job DSLs.

content.raw:
If you look at the build parameters for the ci and pr-any jobs for servicesim, there are actually two :dizzy_face: RTOOLS_BRANCH parameter fields. The first is the default one from the base job config and the latter is one I added while this PR is in review to override that one. In the job that didn't work it appears that you set the first RTOOLS_BRANCH field to add-servicesim but somehow the second was set to default.

The reason I added an override parameter instead of just correcting it by hand is that every time we re-run the job generation it will undo that by-hand correction. So this seemed like the best way to consistently force the use of the add-servicesim branch.

I'm not sure what the usual procedure for review on the release tools branch is. I think we've got things pretty well dialed in for servicesim CI so I think this branch is ready to merge pending review.
content.html:
If you look at the build parameters for the ci and pr-any jobs for servicesim, there are actually two RTOOLS_BRANCH parameter fields. The first is the default one from the base job config and the latter is one I added while this PR is in review to override that one. In the job that didn't work it appears that you set the first RTOOLS_BRANCH field to add-servicesim but somehow the second was set to default.

The reason I added an override parameter instead of just correcting it by hand is that every time we re-run the job generation it will undo that by-hand correction. So this seemed like the best way to consistently force the use of the add-servicesim branch.

I'm not sure what the usual procedure for review on the release tools branch is. I think we've got things pretty well dialed in for servicesim CI so I think this branch is ready to merge pending review.

pull_request.title: Add servicesim job to job DSLs.

pullrequest.title: Add servicesim job to job DSLs.

content.raw:
Update on the above todos.

the servicesim compilation script has been written. It uses a modified buildsh generator script that runs catkin_make_isolated instead of catkin tools. 

The supported distros are in fact only xenial-amd64  :white_check_mark:.

The Debian packaging jobs have been added to the dsl script. When new packages are added to the project they'll need to be added to the `servicesim_packages` list in servicesim.dsl.
content.html:
Update on the above todos.

the servicesim compilation script has been written. It uses a modified buildsh generator script that runs catkin_make_isolated instead of catkin tools.

The supported distros are in fact only xenial-amd64 .

The Debian packaging jobs have been added to the dsl script. When new packages are added to the project they'll need to be added to the servicesim_packages list in servicesim.dsl.
